title: ag.algebraic geometry - Counting points in elliptic curves
body: Given an elliptic curve over $\mathbb Z_n$ Is it $\#P$ hard to compute $\# E(\mathbb Z_n)$ ? Is it $PP$ -hard to compute $\# E(\mathbb Z_n)\leq\frac n2$ ? Is it $\oplus P$ hard to compute $\# E(\mathbb Z_n)\bmod 2$ ? ag.algebraic-geometry nt.number-theory arithmetic-geometry elliptic-curves computational-complexity Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 10, 2020 at 14:37 asked Jul 10, 2020 at 14:11 VS. 1,846 1 1 gold badge 12 12 silver badges 27 27 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 10 2 $\begingroup$ Could you define what you call an elliptic curve over $\Bbb{Z}_n$? $\endgroup$ abx –  abx 2020-07-10 14:22:50 +00:00 Commented Jul 10, 2020 at 14:22 $\begingroup$ Sorry I was thinking on this mathoverflow.net/questions/95408/elliptic-curves-over-rings . If not appropriate I can take it down or just use $\mathbb F_q$ since that does not change the nature of the question. $\endgroup$ VS. –  VS. 2020-07-10 14:24:16 +00:00 Commented Jul 10, 2020 at 14:24 1 $\begingroup$ And even define $\mathbb{Z}_n$ as it's both used for $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ and for the $n$-adics (projective limit of $\mathbb{Z}/n^k\mathbb{Z}$). $\endgroup$ YCor –  YCor 2020-07-10 14:30:39 +00:00 Commented Jul 10, 2020 at 14:30 6 $\begingroup$ For $n$ prime we have Schoof's algorithm which is polynomial in the number of bits, so all these problems are in $P$. For other $n$ the hardest step might be factoring, which is not believed to be polynomial time, but also not expected to be hard for any of these hardness classes. $\endgroup$ Will Sawin –  Will Sawin 2020-07-10 15:17:35 +00:00 Commented Jul 10, 2020 at 15:17 3 $\begingroup$ For a reference, see the Wikipedia page on "Counting points on elliptic curves" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counting_points_on_elliptic_curves $\endgroup$ Will Sawin –  Will Sawin 2020-07-10 15:23:42 +00:00 Commented Jul 10, 2020 at 15:23  |  Show 5 more comments 0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
